docs.lead_paragraph: The House passed a bill on Wednesday making it a federal crime for any adult to transport an under-age girl across state lines to have an abortion without the consent of her parents. A vote on a similar bill is expected in the Senate later this spring or early this summer, and backers says its chances are good. The measure, the Child Interstate Abortion Notification Act, passed 270 to 157 and was a victory for abortion opponents, who have been pushing an ambitious agenda now that Congress is under greater Republican control.

headline.main: House Tightens Parental Rule For Abortions

docs.abstract: House passes bill making it federal crime for any adult to transport under-age girl across state lines to have abortion without consent of her parents; vote is 270 to 157; Senate to vote on similar bill within few months; House measure is victory for abortion opponents, who are pushing ambitious agenda now that Congress is under greater Republican control; bill also requires doctors who perform abortions on girls 17 and under to comply with state notification law, and in some cases to notify girl's parents in person; violators could face $100,000 fine and year in jail; bill also imposes 24-hour waiting period for young women who travel to another state for abortion, in some cases even if they are accompanied by their parents; measure has strong backing of White House; opponents say measure would violate Supreme Court ruling that requires state parental notification laws to include alternatives, like permitting abortions with judge's consent (M)
docs.snippet: The measure makes it a federal crime for any adult to transport an under-age girl across state lines to have an abortion without the consent of her parents.

docs.lead_paragraph: A teenager who the police say left her newborn daughter in a closet overnight, then showed up at a hospital with the baby's body in a plastic shopping bag the next morning, has been charged with criminally negligent homicide. The mother, Shariece Patterson, 18, of Harlem, left the child's body at St. Luke's Hospital on her way to school on Jan. 24, one day after giving birth at her home on Broadway near 135th Street, the police said yesterday. Ms. Patterson, who had hidden her pregnancy, delivered the baby alone, the police said. An arrest was not made until the medical examiner determined the cause of death, which was asphyxiation, officials said. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenager Accused Of Killing Newborn

byline.original: By Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who agreed to be a surrogate mother for a childless couple gave them five babies, all boys, for less than the price of one on Tuesday. The woman, Teresa Anderson, 25, delivered the quintuplets by Caesarean section. One baby was born with a defective heart, but the others were said to be doing fine.

headline.main: 5 Baby Boys From Surrogate, And at Bargain

docs.snippet: A woman who agreed to be a surrogate mother for a childless couple gave them five babies, all boys, for less than the price of one on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY were once in love. And though they act drunk onstage, their real lives are strictly zero-proof. On one date, they giddily played all four boozy roles -- Martha and George, Nick and Honey -- in Edward Albee's ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf.'' Mireille Enos and David Harbour play Nick and Honey, an opportunistic college professor and his sad, neurotic wife in the current Broadway revival of the 1962 play. The other day, while picking at each other's lunch plates and finishing each other's sentences in a brother-sister way, Ms. Enos and Mr. Harbour talked about their roles (in which they have won good reviews), their own love affair that morphed into friendship, and life lessons culled from Mr. Albee's tale of two miserable, hard-drinking couples, shocking when it had its debut in a pre-Dr. Phil era.

headline.main: They Were Once a Couple, Too, But Never So Awful

docs.snippet: Mireille Enos and David Harbour talk about their roles in "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" and their own love affair that morphed into friendship.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Sleeper Curve SCIENTIST A: Has he asked for anything special? SCIENTIST B: Yes, this morning for breakfast . . . he requested something called ''wheat germ, organic honey and tiger's milk.'' SCIENTIST A: Oh, yes. Those were the charmed substances that some years ago were felt to contain life-preserving properties. SCIENTIST B: You mean there was no deep fat? No steak or cream pies or . . . hot fudge? SCIENTIST A: Those were thought to be unhealthy. from Woody Allen's ''Sleeper''
docs.abstract: Steven Johnson article says that today's popular television programs have complexity that makes greater cognitive demands on viewers than shows had 30 years ago and that this phenomenon, which he calls Sleeper Curve, is enhancing mental development of young people, not retarding it, as television has often been accused of doing; says this applies not only to highbrow dramas like 24, The Sopranos and The West Wing, but also to reality shows like Joe Millionaire, Survivor and The Apprentice; drawings (L)
docs.snippet: Forget what your mother told you: today's prime-time shows are giving you a cognitive workout.

docs.lead_paragraph: MAIN STREET here is filled with Arab shops, from Nablus Sweets and Pastries to butchers, hair salons and Nouri Brothers, an emporium that has taken the concept of the bazaar to Western heights, selling everything from pita bread dusted in oregano and thyme to water pipes, videos and cellphones. For Danae Elon, the town is also a kind of road map to her documentary film, ''Another Road Home,'' much of which is set in a Paterson of mind and memory.

headline.main: Abortion and Civility in the Senate

docs.abstract: James S Mellett letter, responding to David Brooks April 21 column, says Roe v Wade decision rests on weak constitutional grounds
